title: Cannot "reconfigure" specialremote (type=git) ever?
body:
I have repository with a configured special remote (type=git).

```
% git remote -v
myremote    http://localhost:8000/remote/.git (fetch)
myremote    localhost:/tmp/remote (push)
% git annex info
repository mode: indirect
trusted repositories: 0
semitrusted repositories: 4
    00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001 -- web
    00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002 -- bittorrent
    8e48d8ad-e7e7-4cfa-aa78-c4f41d6b7a4c -- myspecialremote [myremote]
    b31e2599-acbb-477f-914a-c99cb7b4b497 -- mih@meiner:/tmp/origin [here]
untrusted repositories: 0
transfers in progress: none
available local disk space: 7.97 gigabytes (+1 megabyte reserved)
local annex keys: 0
local annex size: 0 bytes
annexed files in working tree: 0
size of annexed files in working tree: 0 bytes
bloom filter size: 32 mebibytes (0% full)
backend usage: 
```

Suppose the remote needs to be adjusted, because the http URL changes. How can this be done?

Intuitively, I wanted to declare the present one dead, and create another one:

```
% git annex dead myspecialremote
dead myspecialremote ok
(recording state in git...)
% git annex info
repository mode: indirect
trusted repositories: 0
semitrusted repositories: 3
    00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001 -- web
    00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002 -- bittorrent
    b31e2599-acbb-477f-914a-c99cb7b4b497 -- mih@meiner:/tmp/origin [here]
untrusted repositories: 0
transfers in progress: none
available local disk space: 7.97 gigabytes (+1 megabyte reserved)
local annex keys: 0
local annex size: 0 bytes
annexed files in working tree: 0
size of annexed files in working tree: 0 bytes
bloom filter size: 32 mebibytes (0% full)
backend usage: 
% git annex initremote myspecialremote type=git location=http://localhost:8000/remote/.git autoenable=true 
git-annex: There is already a special remote named "myspecialremote". (Use enableremote to enable an existing special remote.)
```

So while the specialremote seems gone, the name cannot be reused, even for the same URL. And also not for a different URL/remote:

```
% git remote add myremote_new http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git
% git annex initremote myspecialremote type=git location=http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git autoenable=true
git-annex: There is already a special remote named "myspecialremote". (Use enableremote to enable an existing special remote.)
```

Even if I remove the original remote entirely, it does not work:

```
% git remote -v
myremote    http://localhost:8000/remote/.git (fetch)
myremote    localhost:/tmp/remote (push)
myremote_new     http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git (fetch)
myremote_new http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git (push)
% git remote rm myremote
% git remote -v
myremote_new http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git (fetch)
myremote_new http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git (push)
% git annex initremote myspecialremote type=git location=http://localhost:8000/remote_new/.git autoenable=true
git-annex: There is already a special remote named "myspecialremote". (Use enableremote to enable an existing special remote.)
```

@joeyh Am I missing a step, or is there a technical reason why a specialremote name cannot be reused?
